title: Who will win the U.S. Senate election for Michigan in 2020?
preds: It's within .2% and there's 6% left - not sure why so many people have it at 90% for Peters.
To close to call. If the remaining votes go to Dems in a % corresponding to absentee ballots, Dems win.
Strong Democratic base. Polls leaning towards Democratic.

Trump has almost zero chance to win this state as he is double digits behind.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Unlikely in this year for the Republicans to take this seat. Peters has not been a terrific campaigner, but it's still his race to lose.

When you strip out the junk pollsters like Trafalgar, the GOP candidate has never lead in a single poll. About 1/3 of ballots that are going to be cast in Michigan have already been cast. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/michigan/

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

Marist College polling has Peters up by 5-6 points and he has yet to be down in a single September poll. Barring any scandals before or shocks on election day, this race should be comfortable for the Dems moving forward.

Probably overconfident but polls have the Dem consistently in the lead as well as Biden.
This is close but they may need real change; wanting law & order.
Peters holding on to a 7-8 point lead.

Peters has a strong lead in the latest polls and is looking like he will cash in. Want to see a bigger cross-section of polls before ramping things up. [1] [1]https://www.woodtv.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/51/2020/08/JULY-2020_EPIC-MRA-SURVEY.pdf

High chance Gary Peters will be re-elected.

With two Democratic senators, a recent history of skewing blue on a national stage, and a sizable preference for the Dem incumbent in almost all polls, it would take a seismic event to flip this seat.
Peters way ahead. Has incumbency. West side of state more white supremacist; sad to say.

This race is trending very blue. https://projects.jhkforecasts.com/senate-forecast/Michigan Just need to look at the 538 odds and it does not look great.https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/michigan/

High chance Gary Peters will be re-elected.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/michigan/
Mr. James alredy ran for a senate seat in 2018 and did better than expected
High chance Gary Peters will be re-elected.

“A”-rated polls from FiveThirtyEight show incumbent Democrat Gary Peters with a strong lead going into November’s election according to polls conducted in June. [1] No “A” rated polls have been conducted in July at time of writing. I am starting at 65 percent (Probable) in favour of Peters and will revise as appropriate. [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/pollster-ratings/
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/michigan/
Gary Peters is ahead and will be re-elected.
I realize we’re still 4 months out, but something pretty drastic would have to happen to change the outcome of this race.
Peters is the incumbent and has not lost a poll to Jones since March with a large number of double digit differentials.
Latest polls have the Dem with an 8-10 point lead: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/michigan/

Michigan is looking increasingly safe for the Dems, with Biden outperforming among white voters compared to 2016, and Peters is outperforming Biden. The GOP look to be forced to commit resources more defensively than going after a Dem incumbent in a strong position, too.
Monkeys will fly from butt before the GOP wins here.
Change: Dems (+12) Reasoning: Not only is polling looking better but Michigan is going more democratic than the other midwest swing states that went to Trump.
2020 Incumbent Dem senator up against a GOP candidate who has already lost to an incumbent Dem senator in 2018.  Also, a solid lead in the polls: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/michigan/
Poll after poll indicate the incumbent democrat will keep his seat.
Lockdown in Michigan did not go well and voters will remember

-Peters is +12%, +15%, +6%, and +16% in four Michigan polls in June. Biden is +13, +13, +15, +16 over Trump from four MI polls in June. And typically the presidential election has significant bearing on how people vote in other elections down the ticket (including Senate).

Peters hasn't made much of a name for himself. His challenger lost the election for Governor. I think there is enough disaffection with Trump to swing this for Peters. I expect large turnouts in college towns and Detroit to bolster Democratic chances.

Multiple reasons to be bullish on election chances for Peters:
1. Gary Peters is the incumbent. Priors should lean in that direction already. 
2. Great polling for Peters coming out of Michigan already across many polls. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/michigan/
3. Great polling for Biden coming out of Michigan already which will influence congressional races: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/michigan/
4. Popular democratic governor.

Fairly steady lead for the incumbent.
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/mi/michigan_senate_james_vs_peters-6964.html
Solid lead for the at the top of the ticket for Democrats.
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/mi/michigan_trump_vs_biden-6761.html
Advantage Peters.

Peters is popular and has incumbent advantage, and John James already lost once before. Plus our state is rapidly swinging left again. It is unlikely that Trump wins Michigan again, and even less likely that Peters loses his Senate election.
Michigan is running away from the Republican party with a sure win for both Biden and Peters here.
Absentee ballots should really help this year.

Peters (D) is running a solid campaign. He resonates with voters who appreciate his candor and honesty, while also demonstrating his ability to "get things done". Peters has name recognition, whereas James does not. Peters also holds greater influence in the Senate, with a high ranking committee seat.
Because Governor Whitmer mishandled the COVID crisis
Taking an average of my previous forecast and https://projects.jhkforecasts.com/senate-forecast/.
All expert orgs have at least ‘lean dem’

A long way to go but polls show an average lead of 10 points for Peters. Although Michigan is more or less non-partisan the Democrats have won the last five Senatorial elections here. For the above reasons I'm going to say the Democrats have an 83% chance of winning.  Model - 83%
Market - 81%
Crowd - 78%
Weighted Ave. - 81%
It is hard to back Peters too hard as he is at a fundraising disadvantage and Trump did carry the State in 2016 but all the data looks good for him so far and he has an incumbency advantage.

Historical trends suggest a Democrat, however Michigan senate races have been relatively non-competitive.  A competitive presidential race, and few places for Republicans to open the map make it a more credible opportunity.
Updating for current FOX polls. With the latest, the win is soundly for Dems. Inside the 2x MoE. https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/mi/michigan_senate_james_vs_peters-6964.html
Biden won every district in the Michigan Primary

An incumbent political party has lost the election 10 out 19 times (~52.6%) for Class 1, and 8 out of 19 times (~42.1%) for Class 2  in Michigan's Senatorial election history. Given that both incumbents are Democrats, the combined probability of both changing is relatively low.

538 is showing Peters polling clearly higher, between 5-12 points ahead [1]. Peters is the incumbent, so that leans in his direction as well, but his opponent is a big catch for the GOP (an African-American veteran), so there may more for Peters to fight for[2]. Doesn't look like there is much chance for a 3rd party candidate. [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/michigan/
[2] https://www.electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Senate/Maps/May29.html
Michigan is a DNC stronghold, 2016 appears to be more of an aberration and not the norm.
At this point, it appears that Michigan is leaning towards the left.
It will be close. James ads are effective but Peters is overall popular.
Michigan's been hit hard by Corona, and Trump is flagging. But who knows?
Basing data off of polling reported here:  https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/mi/michigan_senate_james_vs_peters-6964.html
Also interesting! Starting with the crowd prior to my own contemplation of likelihood. You all are so smart... I mean that - it is cool!
Absent some scandal, all the indicators point to the Democrat.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_Senate_election_in_Michigan#Results_2
Base rate of 85% reelection for incumbents; 5% bump for substantively different poll numbers for Peters vs his challenger.

Both senate seats in Michigan have been Dem (outside of one term) since the 70's. In 2014, Gary Peters won 55% of the votes to the Republican's 41%. In the 2018 Michigan senate race (maybe less relevant), the win was 52% Dem to 46% Rep.  In 2016, Trump won 47.3% to 47% (Gary Johnson had almost 4%). Bovada currently has the Michigan electoral college -180 Dem (64%) vs. +140 Rep (42%)

Who is Peters is the question for many in Michigan.  Has he really spent 6 years doing nothing?
A military hero, minority business owner and family man taken all together will be the combination for John James 
to win the senate seat for the GOP . Best chance for a Democrat / Republican switch this election.
Polls have Peters (D) up by about 8-9 points. Cook political and Sabato's Crystal Ball have this as lean democrat.
